>>180482062
This is quite an interesting question. It really questions what a name is. My first thought was that names aren't real and aren't really part of us, so whatever a person wants to be called is what will show up on the map. But then anyone could hide from the map by taking a new alias. Not that anyone knows about the map or would care to do this, but at least Pettigrew might have, as he knew about the map and was paranoid and frightened enough to remain a rat for many years. But forgetting that, Pettigrew does have an alias: Wormtail. Nobody ever or very rarely calls Ron 'Ronald', yet that's what comes up on the map, Ronald Weasley. In fact the map always puts everyones full name. So that makes me think the map will always put the name you were given at birth... right? Wrong. Married women on the map who have officially had their surname changed by the man they married, Molly Weasley for example, are updated - but people who go by a nickname more than their real name are NOT recognised by the map. So what does that mean? It means there is a truth to the connection between a person names and their identity, at least according to the creators of map. So to answer your question, it's not whether the map would deadname trannies, but whether James and Sirius would (as they were the leaders), and I think we both know the answer is yes.

It's not possible for working directors to have good favorite film lists.

A good list would have contemporary films on it, like Winter Sleep, Four Lions, Still Walking, The Act of Killing, Leave no Trace, Certain Women, Kill List or Phantom Thread etc etc etc etc.

He can't say those though, because then he's going to come off like a fanboy of his peers, which can generate bullshit media attention for him, or just make him look not cool.
A list of his favourite classic films is then probably either going to look basic or pretentious. There's no winning. And it's not going to be a good list unless you put a lot of thought into it which he probably hasn't.

A better question is to ask someone what films they've enjoyed the most recently.

The way I see it anyone in their sixties can play a big role and anyone fifties or younger can do that plus take part in action scenes. Past that we are into cameo territory. Its probably even true for Martok who is really old and seems like he had more makeup than most Klingons.

That functionally leaves us with Worf (I consider this borderline and we'll see how he does in PIC), Bashir & Ezri & brother, Jake & Kasidy, Miles & Keiko & Molly (take your pick), and Morn. This is before even looking into which actors might be hard retired or in prison or anything like that. Could you write a good story with those characters? That continues the narrative or themes? That you'd want to see?

I think the most obvious thing to do would have a scenaio that is sort of like a reverse Occupation. Like we know Cardassia got buttfucked and Bajor was actually doing alright and getting their feet underthem. So add some new characters to play like the "next generation" of bajorans and cardassians and have the old cast get involved in the bullshit. Like maybe Bajor is there trying to do humanitarian shit. And they move Terek Nor there to act as a base to run their operations from (they've built a new cooler station near the wormhole for their religious stuff because they never liked it being Cardi originally). Miles gets called out to help them figure out something he jury-rigged decades ago that no one else can make heads or tales off and he ends up sticking arounf for "reasons. Obviously Keiko and Molly could be party to that. Kira being there should be obvious. Bashier and Ezri seem almost as obvious a fit (medical and psychological help to the people of a collapsed society they already had ties to). This would allow plenty of cameos for old Cardassian characters, even holovids and memorial shit for dead ones. Jake being a reporter/writer fits both in the disaster relief side as well as the moving of a legendary station and we know Kasidy's cargo routes took her to planets all around there. Shakaar could be leader of the Bajoran government and like give a speech or issue orders to Kira or something as a cameo. Maybe a we could get a cameo about Quark selling his bar and Brunt being involved in that (allows references to Rom and Zek). Only people that don't immediately fit in that would be the Klingons and Section 31, but I think that's fine.

I agree, it was weird and made me wonder if there was real life actor shit involved (i.e. some actors wanted out or had other gigs lined up).
Maybe it's just bad writing though; the whole shit with the Gorn is deeply retarded and tiresome.

Like yeah, okay, they're supposed to be a horror thing (a staple of trek) but like they're just a dumb animal thing with martial prowess and some mastery of biology; who fucking cares in an age of lasers and super advanced medical science?
Sure they have no or few medical counter measures right this second (or even that may not be true; I don't quite recall) but they're going to.
Plus the Gorn's species requires humanoids as an intermediate host as part of their life cycle? What did they do for the periods of time before they could travel to other worlds to steal people (who are somehow compatible)?
And how long is a species like this going to prosper before literally everyone, regardless of creed or religion or political affiliation, gangs up on them to eradicate them from the galaxy?
It's one thing for the Klingons to be assholes that bully weaker races and take slaves; the people they trade with are strong enough that it's not worth it for the Klingons to rob them (mostly) yet the Klingons are sufficiently able to engage in trade such that the people they trade with are willing to engage in trade (likely because Klingons can't count for shit and probably get fucking fleeced on every transaction).
But there's no leeway like that for the Gorn; they're just dumb monsters that kidnap people and consign them to a slow death.

>>180482469
I mean it can work, but only if the main story actually works as a story. A lot of recent horror films bank on just being a metaphor dressed up as a horror film, that’s what makes it bad because you can easily see through it. Because then you have an easy explanation for what’s happening, which deflates all the feelings that horror is supposed to create (tension, mystery, spookiness). If I can go ‘Oh I see the monster and atmosphere are a metaphor for dementia’ then I can just switch my brain off after that (this is a real example, Relic).

But you can have good horror movies that might have a metaphorical interpretation, or they might not, or they might accept different readings, say The Exorcist. Then it works.

>>180482323
>But that's obviously false
No it isn't obvious nor is it false. I wish you had dropped the "obvious" when this is a complex topic, not the easy one the three of you seem to think it is. My point is that this doesn't make any sense, and thus people shouldn't be gushing over how "deep" it is, and it stems from my actual understand of the concept of memory.
>Those are things that are physically built into your brain as you have new experiences
Yes but after saying this you should realize what a memory is. The simplest unit of memory is an "engram" just two neurons firing together. You add a third neuron and the three can fire in a plethora of different sequences. You add several million and the whole group can fire in a complex manner which "stores" memories. Giving someone memories is giving them this effect. You actually give them your brain by training the neurons to fire in the specific sequence that stored the memory. Saying "it wouldn't have the same brain as you" is the thing that's false. Even if you didn't know this, think of the meaning of a memory (experience). Say I've learned self control around fire. Why? Because I touched a flame as a child, burned my finger, and now have a memory of that event and of the unpleasantry of the pain and I refuse to touch fire again. What is the actual difference between your experience and your memory of said experience?

>>180482429
Interestingly, through this conversation, I've realized that what they should have done is focused on emotions. Emotions are a very strong part of memory and if we already know replicants don't or shouldn't have any this should be the thing that prevents gaining "experience." For example, it's not enough to just remember that I touched fire, it's the fear and the intense desire to be free of pain that solidifies the lesson. It's not just about remembering that someone was injured when I drove drunk, it's the despair I felt when I had hurt someone that caused be to never want to do it again. If the replicant just has the knowledge, but doesn't understand the emotions tied to it, then they won't really grasp the lesson and won't respond like humans do. However, because the author was trying to be "deep" he writes a character with unrestrained emotions and blames it on the fact that they received memories, not on a child's lack of brain development.

>>180482824
Not the people you've been arguing with but:

1) The real facts are laid out in the source material, the book. The movie alludes to some of the ideas but not all of them or drops some of them (for example in the book 'Do Androids Dream of Electronic Sheep?')

2) In the book they don't just lack experience; they're augmented humans that both have significant physiologic differences due to their augmentation, as well as deliberate defects to shorten their lifespan, as well as a lack of real experience.
In the book they aren't immature, they're flat out neurologically damaged; most have flat affect, and when presented with emotionally complex stimuli their brains can't handle it and they freak out.
In the movie the shortened lifespan is a byproduct of their super human abilities and a defect the Tyrell corporation wants to fix. In the movie (and I think the book?) Tyrell's whole goal is to resurrect his dead niece and maybe replace humanity with superior replicants.
In the book humanity killed earth with an unspecified super war or some other disaster that caused most of the surviving populace to abandon earth for outworld colonies, and for the people on earth (and presumably off earth as well) to adopt a new religion called Mercerism that is founded on Empathy (something the replicants ostensibly lack, although a theme of the book is that they don't lack it, it's just they've been told they lack it so they've made it true for themselves).

At the risk of handwaving, in the book it's implied that there's a certain amount of cybernetics or unspecified tinkering that has occurred with the replicants that goes beyond genetic manipulation, so a charitable response to the brain maturity problem you're getting at (one related to the presence or absence of the hormones that cause the final changes to the human brain around age 25) the one telling the story is Deckard and he only knows what he needs to know about Replicants.

posts.com:
'Decision to Leave' is a film that plays on metaphors, plays on opposite extremes- like the sea and the mountain. The detective says and does contradictory things- he orders his coworkers to not eat expensive meals but brings expensive sushi for the suspect. When his wife asks him to bring sushi, he refuses to do so by making up an alibi. The growing disconnect between the detective and his wife is seen when the director takes away the focus from the detective having sex with his wife to a sex scene on the TV with only the girl in view, showing how the sexual relationship has only one interested party left. The focus then shifts to sex with a skeleton insisting on how the love between the couple has died. This follows up with the detective lying to his wife about the case. The death of love culminates in the scene where Song goes to the mountain to blow away her grandfather's ashes metaphorising blowing away the ashes of love between the detective and his wife.

While the distance between the detective and his wife grows, it shortens between him and the suspect. When he is staking out Song through binoculars, he is shown to be in her space- smelling her, feeling her. They start having inside jokes now. They share a laugh over Song's insufficient Korean- they laugh over the word solitary during an investigation, symbolising laughing away his loneliness. After the investigation, the detective starts cleaning the table, but the suspect takes over the cleaning cloth from his hand. Only their hands are shown as if a married couple's.

posts.com: Decision to Leave pays homage to Hitchcockian masterpieces, most prominently Vertigo (1958), but offers his own spin on the neo-noir genre. He partly does it through Tang Wei’s Song Seo-rae, who is a far more grounded and humane femme fatale. The film establishes, beyond doubt, that she is indeed a murderess like Sharon Stone’s Catherine Tramell, but unlike the latter, she kills only because of love and self-defense. Her first murder was a mercy killing as she performed euthanasia on her mother, who requested it from her. Her second murder was Ki Do-soo, who battered her and branded her as his own. Even then, it was only under his threat of deportation that she finally decided to do away with him. Next, as she knew what was going to happen once Chul-sung’s mother dies, she helped her pass quietly to protect Hae-joon’s secret.

There are many plot holes and stupid decisions in these books. Mostly because Rowling didnt consider the scale of things, or because she introduced things in the later books that would have solved problems in the earlier books. Thats ok, I still like the books, they are great.

The biggest problem for me though is the trip wizard tournament. Its clearly meant to be a big spectacle. Everyone is talking about how exciting it is, they cancel quidditch for it, etc. And the first task is a great spectacle! Everyone watches them fight dragons.
HOWEVER
the second and third task cannot be seen by the spectators. They sit and watch a lake, or a maze, with no idea what is going on under the water or inside the maze. Just, sitting there for an hour, watching the lake or the maze with nothing happening at all. Why she chose to do it like that is absolutely baffling. It bothered me immediately when I first read the book at 14 and it still bothers me to this day. Ridiculous.

Firelight is a 1964 American science fiction adventure film written and directed by Steven Spielberg at the age of 17.[3][4] Made on a budget of $500, the film was shown at a local cinema and generated a profit of $1.[4] "I counted the receipts that night", Spielberg has recalled, "And we charged a dollar a ticket. Five hundred people came to the movie and I think somebody probably paid two dollars, because we made one dollar profit that night, and that was it."[5][6]

Only three minutes and forty seconds of footage has been made public, about 3% of the original length. Spielberg returned to its subject matter for his third major film, Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>180477476
I think a lot of it is the finality of it. Movies on home video probably aren't going to get better than their 4K release in the future, so they put a steep price on it, knowing they won't be reselling that movie again. They were able to sell the same movie to the same people on VHS, sometimes laserdisc, DVD, and blu-ray, and now 4K puts an end to the re-release gravy train, so they might as well get all they can for it.
